fields.name: Gen Z
fields.description: Slang terms popularized by Generation Z, often originating from social media platforms like TikTok and Instagram.

fields.name: Hinglish
fields.description: A blend of Hindi and English slang, commonly used by Indian Gen Z on social media.

fields.name: Gujarati
fields.description: Slang terms rooted in the Gujarati language, often used humorously by Gen Z in India.

fields.meaning: To throw something with force or enthusiasm; also used as an exclamation of excitement.
fields.origin: US Gen Z, popularized through Vine and TikTok in the mid-2010s.
fields.usage_example: I yeeted my phone across the room when I got the news!
fields.cultural_origin: African American Vernacular English (AAVE) and internet culture.

fields.origin: US Gen Z, widely used on social media since the early 2010s.
fields.usage_example: The party last night was so lit!

fields.meaning: Short for charisma; the ability to charm or flirt with someone.
fields.origin: Popularized by TikTok in 2022, derived from charisma.
fields.usage_example: He’s got so much rizz, he charmed everyone at the party.
fields.cultural_origin: Internet culture, Gen Z social media trends.

fields.meaning: Short for delusional; used to describe someone with unrealistic beliefs or fantasies.
fields.origin: TikTok trend starting around 2023, often used humorously.
fields.usage_example: She’s so delulu if she thinks he’s texting her back.

fields.meaning: A metaphorical score of someone’s vibe or energy, often used to describe coolness or presence.
fields.origin: Emerged on TikTok in 2024, reflecting Gen Z’s focus on vibes.
fields.usage_example: He gained aura points for that confident speech.
fields.cultural_origin: Internet culture, Gen Z social media trends.

fields.meaning: Brother; used affectionately or humorously to refer to a friend.
fields.origin: Common in Indian Gen Z conversations, especially on WhatsApp and Instagram.
fields.usage_example: Bhai, let’s grab some chai after class.
fields.cultural_origin: Hindi language, widely used in Hinglish contexts.

fields.meaning: How are you? Often used playfully or ironically.
fields.origin: Traditional Gujarati greeting, repurposed by Gen Z for humor.
fields.usage_example: Kem cho, bro? Ready for the party?
fields.cultural_origin: Gujarati language, used in Indian Gen Z circles.
